Posts.Content: Liane wrote: I am brand new to this forum and am so grateful to have found it.  I am supposed to start chemo this week but have some hesitation.  I met with my oncologist earlier and he told me that my oncotype dx test showed that chemo would help only 1-2%.  He said that my benefit would come from hormonal therapy.  I would like ot know if anyone is in the grey area of chemo and what considerations were made in choosing to move forward with chemo, or just to take hormonal treatment.  The real question is "how toxic is the toxicity from chemo (specifically TC for 4 treatments over 12 weeks, 1/3 weeks).  If anyone has advice, I would appreciate the input. Thanks! Diagnosed 5/30/11, stage 1, 1.5 cm, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: July Chemo Liane vlnrph

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 10:40AM Liane wrote: OMG!  My entire post just got erased too.  Anyways, since I wrote my initial post, I got a 3rd opinion which came with a late night phoe call the day before chemo.  I really wanted an outside opinion from a reputable research institution and called Dr. Hope Rugo at UCSF.  She was great!  My husband is a doc so she spoke to him and I listened in.  She said that I would benefit since my oncotype dx score was 24, a high intermediate score.  One other doc said that I would benefit only 1-2% but I don't believe him, and the other said 5-6%.  Who really knows but I am risk adversed and elected for a bliateral mastectomy so I am not taking chances now.  With you, I think the docs would give different advice.  They based it on your score and your tumor size, grade and all the other markers.  You are early so chemo may not be best given the toxicity risk.  My side affects have been minimal so far, although I expect them to get worse later.  I decided that for peace of mind, I must get through this.  For you, possibly call a reputable oncologist in your area and ask for one more opinion.  Keep me posted.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 01:03AM Liane wrote: I was diagnosed about 5 weeks ago and this has been a really tough time.  I worry most about the recurrence and asked my doctor the same question.  I was told that 80% of BCs are cured.  I was also read that even in stage 1, 20-30% of people with stage 1 have circulating cells that could cause a recurrence later.  I did a little research and found that surgery (and radiation or mastectomy only) could cure people, but not always.  In those 20-30% of people with circulating BC cells,  these cells could find a niche in the body and hide, remaining dormant even during chemo.  Years later, they could become active triggering a recurrence.  Chemo will kill most or all of the active cells, but possibly not the dormant ones.  But tamoxifen could change the environment and neighborhood to prevent growth of that cell later.  The BC cell may die if the evironment is not favorable for growth and this is how cancer can be cured even when cells are not entirely caught with surgery.  If the neighborhood is changed permanently, the cell will never grow, even long after tamoxifen is stopped.  So yes, a cure is possible with chemo and Tamoxifen.  I have a question-my doctor said that the oncotype dx test revealed that I would only benefit 1-2% from chemo treatments (TC).  I am conflicted on whether I should go forward with chemo, given the toxicity risk.  Any advice???
Posts.Title: Adjvnt Therapy: Destroys or delays growth of stray BC cells? SusansGarden Omaz
